page.title: User Manual

section.title: Actions
section.p: Once a Pingu is out of the entrance, he will be falling to ground. As a Faller he can't do anything but just obey the law gravity. If the Pingu falls for too long, he will gather too speed and so won't survive on hitting the ground. So be and keep an eye on the height of objects from which they safely fall.

subsection.title: The Walker
subsection.p: If the Pingu has fallen from the entrance and safely the ground, the Pingu will turn into a Walker. The Walker is state in which the Pingu will be most of the time. As a Walker Pingu simply moves in the current direction in which he is facing. He will walk in this way until you give him a command to something else. However, if the Pingu reaches an obstacle that cannot walk up or through, he will turn around and walk back the opposite direction.

subsection.title: The Digger
subsection.p: When a Pingu is turned into a Digger, he digging/drilling a vertical hole through any object that would otherwise walk on. A Digger continues digging a hole there is nothing below it to dig, in which case the Digger fall, or the Digger hits a solid object, such as metal.

subsection.title: The Basher
subsection.p: A Basher is the horizontal equivalent of a Digger. A bashes out a tunnel through any object that is ahead of it. stops bashing when there is nothing ahead to bash, a solid has been reached, such as metal, or there is nothing below Basher. In the latter case, the Basher will fall.

subsection.title: The Miner
subsection.p: The Miner can be considered to be a combination of a Digger a Basher. Whereas a Digger only goes down and a Basher only forward, the Miner goes down and forward in one movement. results in a tunnel going diagonally downwards. Like a Digger a Basher, a Miner stops if there is nothing to mine, a object has been reached or there is nothing below the Miner. the latter case, the Miner will fall.

subsection.title: The Blocker
subsection.p: The blocker stops at its current position and then starts command other Pingus which reach him to change their direction. Pingu can thus pass a Blocker. Instead they will turn around head in the other direction.

subsection.title: The Bomber
subsection.p: Sometimes when you have to stop a Pingu or have to create hole, but have neither a Basher nor a Miner, there is no way than to turn a Pingu into a Bomber. The Pingu will start countdown once he has turned into a Bomber. He will continue current action until the countdown reaches zero. On zero reached, he will inflate and then explode. The explosion create a hole in the ground and destroy anything that is near him. Thus a Bomber can be used to either make holes or to Blockers or other Pingus that are in the way.

subsection.title: The Bridger
subsection.p: A Pingu turned into a Bridger will start to build a bridge. It will not be a large bridge and goes slightly upwards. In most cases this will be enough to reach a higher point or pass a deep hole in the ground.

subsection.title: The Climber
subsection.p: A Pingu that has learned the ability to climb will be able climb on vertical objects which normal Pingus cannot climb. Climber will climb to the top of an object that would block his way. Once at the top, he will turn back into a Walker. A Pingu that has learnt the ability to Climb will keep it, you can see which Pingus can climb and which can't by little [c] in the info box that appears if you place cursor on a Pingu.

subsection.title: The Floater
subsection.p: Like the Climber action, the Floater action will also stay the Pingu once it is applied. This time you can see which can float by the little [f] in the info box of the Pingu. A Pingu that can Float will use his propeller-hat to reduce falling speed during a fall. Once he has his propeller-hat on, will be slow enough to not die on hitting the ground. So Floater action protects the Pingu from high falls, which a Pingu would not survive.

subsection.title: The Jumper
subsection.p: A Pingu that gets turned into a Jumper will gather all power and start a single large jump forward. He will not jump high, but pretty far and pretty fast. He can thus reach platforms or get past situations in which he can't stay too in one place.

subsection.title: The Slider
subsection.p: Once you give a Pingu the command to become a Slider, he jump on his belly and move forward with a lot of speed. But careful. To get the speed, the Pingu needs a perfectly stretch of ground. On bumpy terrain, a Pingu cannot slide far. The Slider is at its best if used on icy ground.

subsection.title: Reverse a Pingu without using Blockers
subsection.p: The usual way of stopping a Pingu from walking off a cliff is to use a Blocker. However, suppose there are no available. How can the direction of a Pingu be reversed so that walks in the opposite direction? Here's how it could be done.

ol.li: Turn the Pingu to be reversed into a Digger.
Let the Digger dig a little bit.
Turn the Digger into a Bridger.

subsection.p: The Bridger should eventually stop building while still the hole, reverse and then walk out of the hole in the direction of the bridge.

subsection.title: Releasing a Blocker without killing him
subsection.p: To release a Blocker in a non-destructive manner, use a Miner dig away the ground underneath it.

subsection.title: Mine the other way
subsection.p: If you have a Builder, a Digger, and a Miner, and you want Pingu to mine down and to the opposite direction of that which it facing, try this trick. Turn it into a Digger momentarily, and it's down four pixels or so, turn it into a Bridger. It will to build its way out of the pit, but then turn around after two or three steps. Now you can have it mine in the opposite direction.

subsection.title: Getting one Pingu out
subsection.p: If you have a Blocker holding in your Pingus, and want to get one Pingu past it without blowing it up, build a bridge that would over the Blocker's head. Then watch the Pingus falling off the end of the bridge. As soon as one falls past the Blocker, make the a Digger. This stops the rest from getting past.

subsection.title: Zig-Zag stairs
subsection.p: If some Pingus are stuck in a pit, they can be freed by numerous Bridgers planting stairs in a zig-zag pattern upward. Each Bridger starts building to the left from the top of a right slanted (which has run into a wall), and vice versa.

subsection.title: Path-finder Pingu
subsection.p: Use one Pingu to blaze a trail across the screen, and then release the others once the route has been completed. Often the Path-finder is an Athlete (Climber and Floater) but not always. If the screen has several trapdoors then you probably need one Path-finder per entrance. In the latter case it's best to try and deal with each trapdoor separately; trying to handle them all at once and skipping from one another is usually doomed to failure.

subsection.title: Building Steps
subsection.p: If a group of Pingus need to fall down from a high structure, you don't have enough Floaters, you can use a Digger Pingu to create step for them. If the drop is twice as far as the Pingus can fall, thereabouts, Have the Digger tunnel down right at the edge of the cliff, and then stop half way. You can stop it by turning it into a Builder. Then the Pingus will fall twice, once to the step the Digger made, then to the ground below. If the drop is farther than that, you can multiple Diggers, staggering them Creating a series of steps.
